message: Question for the mobile developers here: I have zero experience with iOS and Android so excuse my ignorance. I'm working with a vendor that's consuming a RESTful API I'm maintaining and every time they face a problem with the APIs and I ask them for a request sample they give me a hard time and they almost never send an actual request (header, body) nor a response. Their argument is that they can not access the raw request data because neither iOS nor Android SDKs allows them to do so. Like I said I've never touched neither iOS nor Android but I've been writing software for almost two decades under multiple environments and I find that hard to believe, Can this actually be true or are they just incompetent?

data.message: You should have some sort of middle layer like postman or swagger where both of you should use, to make sure languages/libraries/tools don't affect the requests.

I've never needed to do it in android, and it probably need some extra work to get the raw request/response, but you can easily get each component of it like header, body, params...etc on it's own using get methods from the response object

Incompetent is the right word, if I understand you correctly. Unless you are using a binary format, it should be quite easy to capture these details either in logs, or using a proxy (like Charles). As long as we're talking about dev builds here, not live releases.

I would say they just don't have enough experience using other people's APIs and communicating to the backend devs about it... One of the easiest ways to get the full request/response with headers and everything from a mobile app is using Charles proxy, it has a free trial and it's a self-intuitive gui tool, so ideal for that case
One way to do it is to log the request and the response using the adb Tool. Maybe ask them to do that
Fiddler FTW when it comes to dealing with noobs
